review: I bought one without knowing (being told) that I had to use the most up to date IOS (if using iPhone as was the plan; I have Last year's iPhone).  Shocking that it has no backwards compatability.  And something that I should have been told.I bought another router since the one I had was not supported (I was not told that either before I bought it; that information is nowhere on the Amazon page and hard to find that out on the Google pages).  So I wasted another $80, and if Amazon had told me that I would have to do so I would not have bought the Chromecast.I wasted over an hour trying everything suggested, spent the money, and when I called Google I was told there is no solution for me other than buying more stuff that I otherwise don't need.Did I mention that the Chromecast keeps turning the TV on in the middle of the night?  Try that if you want to be freaked.Larry Burnett
author: L. W. Burnett

review: I was very excited about the arrival of the Chromecast. Everyone got one for Christmas this year. I really like the concept of a streaming device that plugs right into the TV like this instead of being a box in the entertainment center. The device is a lot of fun if you want to watch YouTube or Netflix but it doesn't meet some of my other hopes. I am on the lookout for a single device solution. We have a Roku and that has almost everything we want to stream but doesn't do iTunes. We have an Apple TV and that has many streaming features but doesn't have Amazon Prime. Now we have the Chromecast and it doesn't have iTunes OR Amazon (and streaming Amazon through the browser requires the removal of Silverlight and then the video lags frequently). Amazon and iTunes are not likely to show up any time soon either - since Google has their own competing service. But overall, it works as well as any of the other streaming devices we have and the decision to purchase this device or one of the other competitors really comes down to which service you prefer.

review: Has some limitations, but overall very useful.  For example, widescreen videos are distorted to fit a standard TV (maybe not a problem on an HD set).  Had to purchase an HDMI to RCA converter since my older TV does not have HDMI, but it works fine.  The colors may be a bit distorted.  On the movies I have viewed so far, the color on the PC is blue-tinted but on the TV the colors are somewhat green-tinted.  (The TV actually looks more natural; don't know which is the "true" color.)  Documentation is non-existent, but there are some good references on Amazon.  (Interesting:  setup using Chrome failed, could not find my network, but setup using IE worked first time - go figure.)  Very worthwhile especially considering the price.
